docs.lead_paragraph: ''Got milk?'' cries the National Dairy Council, seeking to reverse or at least stem a half-century decline in per capita consumption of this nutrient-packed beverage. ''Got beer?'' countered the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine, a nonprofit organization that promotes milk-free vegetarian diets and in 1992 denounced the feeding of cows' milk to children.

headline.main: Debate Over Milk: Time to Look at Facts

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column reviews common beliefs and scientific facts about milk's relationship to health and various disorders (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If a child at the Enrico Fermi School in Yonkers is found to have attention deficit disorder, parents can choose an unusual alternative to medication: neurofeedback, a computerized biofeedback system that some say strengthens the brain. Linda Vergara, the school's principal, said she decided to try the approach when doctors diagnosed the disorder in her son in 1992. ''They told me I needed to give him something to calm him down,'' she said.

headline.main: Some See Hope in Biofeedback for Attention Disorder

docs.abstract: Some parents whose child is found to have attention deficit disorder can choose unusual alternative to medication: neurofeedback, a computerized biofeedback system that some say strengthens brain; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''More Chicken Soup and Other Folk Remedies,'' by Joan Wilen and Lydia Wilen (Ballantine Books, $14). Somewhere around the 16th century, the Swiss alchemist Paracelsus mixed mineral gold and salt and then let it ''digest'' in horse dung. When laced with wine, and drunk every day precisely at dawn, the elixir was supposed to cure all diseases of the mind and body. Blessedly, this entertaining little sequel to the Wilen sisters' earlier testimonial to folk remedies does not contain any Paracelsian cure-alls -- but some come awfully close.

headline.main: Folk Remedies, Off the Shelf and Off the Wall

docs.abstract: John Langone assesses facts and fiction in folk remedies suggested in book More Chicken Soup and Other Folk Remedies, by Joan Wilen and Lydia Wilen; cover photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A month after badly breaking her left leg and blowing out her right knee in a skiing crash in Switzerland, Picabo Street, the fearless, spunky media darling of the 1998 Nagano Olympics, shut herself in the bedroom of her parents' house and closed the blinds. She would not let family or friends in, she took no phone calls, did not watch television, did nothing for weeks but lie there in the darkened room thinking miserable thoughts. ''I went through a huge depression,'' Ms. Street said. ''I went all the way to rock bottom. I never thought that I ever would experience anything like that in my life.''

headline.main: Athletes' Injuries Go Beyond the Physical

docs.abstract: Athletes who suffer injuries, even weekend athletes, are susceptible to depression, anxiety and other psychological symptoms, including nightmares, flashbacks to the accident, moodiness, irritability, fatigue, insomnia, weight gain and low self-esteem; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists long thought that sinusitis, the most common long-term disease in the United States, was caused by allergies or by bacteria trapped inside the labyrinthine sinuses. And over the years, doctors have tried a variety of treatments, as drastic as surgery, for chronic coldlike symptoms with limited success. Then last year, researchers at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., reported that they had found another possible cause: an overly aggressive immune reaction to fungi in the nose. ''It is a total shift of the paradigm,'' said Dr. Jens Ponikau, one of the Mayo researchers.

headline.main: Study Ties Sinusitis To Fungi In the Nose

docs.abstract: Researchers at Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn, say they have found another possible cause of sinusitis: overly aggressive immune reaction to fungi in the nose (M)
